item.description:
Mashup! Everybody is doing it, so why can't we?

We live in the age of the "experience economy," social scientists and marketers of all stripes tell us. It's all about the "experience," as if this concept was freshly thought up. Just what do they mean? Well, as far as I can tell, it's about using "experience" as a verb, which one dictionary defines as "to participate in personally; undergo." So, instead of serving you a ready-made something, "they," whoever they may be, would like to offer you something that you would like to participate in, and in so doing alter it and make it your own. That's the idea.

Now you see where mashup comes in? It's about taking different things, toying with them, and coming up with something altered. Musicians do it, tech people do it, even museum curators are dabbling in it...so we can try it too. Let's read Nikolai Gogol's classic story "The Nose," about a man who lost control of his nose and discuss it alongside a recent and unusual story/essay by Miranda July irresistably titled, "Shoplifting to Stay Free." (find it below) And then let's see what happens...

http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2011/10/10/111010fa_fact_july

group.name: Classic Books: Book Club for Die-hard Readers

item.name: Mashup: Gogol's "The Nose" + July's "Shoplifting to Stay Free"
